notLoggedIn.heading: Create a developer account first.
notLoggedIn.paragraphOne: Our API Portal enables you to register a free team-based account on the fly.
notLoggedIn.paragraphTwo:
Once activated, we assist you in 3 straightforward steps to start consuming our API products.

Not sure how to get there? The onboarding documentation will help you along.

loggedIn.heading: We value you as an interested developer!
loggedIn.paragraphOne: enables you to register your client apps and subscribe to our available API products.
loggedIn.paragraphTwo:
Whenever you are ready, we assist you in 3 straightforward steps to start consuming our API products.

Did you experience any issues with your account set-up?

stepOne.paragraph:
You'll need an app to send and receive API calls.

Adding your app details will help us to enable this flow.

stepTwo.paragraph: In the "Subscriptions" section, we provide an overview of our available Sandbox APIs your apps can subscribe to.

stepThree.paragraph: Once your app and API subscriptions are all ready to go, head to our "Getting Started" documentation for lift-off.

stepOne.stepText: We begin by retrieving a unique token ID. We will use this token in the following requests so the API can verify your identity. Make a POST request with the parameters as shown below. Replace the variables with the Client ID and Client Secret of one of your Apps.
stepOne.stepNote: Manage and see each of your Apps' details by navigating to the "Client Applications" tab. You can find the Client ID and Client Secret under the "Access Details" section on the app's page.

stepTwo.stepText: Let's upload some data to the API by making another POST request with a JSON containing our cat's (i.e., Jack) data.

stepThree.stepText: Now we can test the API using a simplet GET request to retrieve some data.
stepThree.response: The response should look like this:

testSubTab.title: How to use and test your API
testSubTab.description: These are some quick instructions on how you can upload data to your API, and test it.
testSubTab.finalRemarksPartTwo: Now you know how to do it. That's how easy it is to get your API up and running!

documentation.default:
# How to use and test your API

These are some quick instructions on how you can interact with your subscribed API.

## Step 1: Get the API Key

In order to interact with the API you will need the `apikey` that matches the app subscription you are using in your request header to be able to access.

Use the app `Client Id` as the `apikey` header.

## Step 2: Authentication (optional)

Some APIs will require you to retrieve a unique token ID. This token can be used in the requests so the API can verify your identity. The following POST request is an example of how you may get the token depending on your setup. Replace the variables with the Client ID and Client Secret of one of your Apps.

```shell
curl -X POST \\
-H "Host: gateway.address" \\
-H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" \\
-u "{ClientID}:{ClientSecret}" \\
--data-urlencode "grant_type=client_credentials" \\
https://gateway.address/oauth2/token
```

## Step 3: Make a request to the API

Now with the `apikey` added to the header you can make a request to GET or POST data.

### POST

```shell
curl -X POST \\
-H "Accept: application/json" \\
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \\
-H "apikey: APIKEY_VALUE" \\
-d '{"name": "Jack Daniels", "desc": "My cat", "tag": "cat"}' \\
https://gateway.address/v1/pets
```

### GET

```shell
curl -X GET \\
-H "apikey: APIKEY_VALUE" \\
https://gateway.address/v1/pets
```

subscriptions.title: Subscriptions
subscriptions.description: The {{config.clientName}} Sandbox can hold an unlimited amount of API Products and API versions. The former defines the business side of an API, the latter is the technical entry, defined by OpenAPI contracts. This view enables you to automate deprecation control and give better insight in how the APIâ€™s and applications are linked together.

pages.default:
# No content

This page has no content. You can create content for it by using the "pages" API.

To add the content you'll need to set the following parameters:

- id: the page name that will appear in the url you are trying to access (i.e. `documentation`)
- content: the markdown content to show
- locale (optional): the language the document is in (default is `en-US`)

:::info
*Make sure your request is authenticated with correct authorised cookie.*

:::

```shell
curl -X POST \\
-H "Accept: application/json" \\
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \\
-d '{ "id": "documentation", "locale": "en-US", "content": "# Documentation\n\nThis is a documentation page" }' \\
https://apisuite/pages
```

#### Notes

Side navigation is only shown for the level 2 header (i.e. `h2`, `##`)
